column1: 5.0 out of 5 stars;Ignore bad reviews;"Ok
column2: to start
column3: I have been buying HTC phones for years. Even when I decide to buy a more mainstream phone I end up taking it back for one reason or another. I will not spend this review bashing the other ""leaders"" of phones out there. If they work for you great
column4: I will state why I prefer HTC phones.1-LCD screen
column5: if you want a screen that looks good and doesn't degrade the instant it is turned on (fact about ALL amoleds
column7: not talking about video run time or anything like that
column8: I fully believe those are subjective
column9: what I mean is when I sit the phone down
column10: not sure if it is just Android Doze or if HTC does something on top of it
column11: but when I do NOT charge the phone at night and it only loses 3-5% battery life
column13: only other phone I had that came close was Pixel 2
column15: I have read a lot of ""reviews"" where this function is completely flamed hard
column16: all I have to say is that if you don't like it
column17: turn it off. But day to day use is fantastic
column18: I use it regularly and if you have a job where you may have gloves on or any situation where you don't have finger dexterity
column19: squeezing to start camera and squeeze to take the picture is invaluable. 4-Skin
column20: I feel for the most part that HTC doesn't mess with what is not broken
column21: they embrace existing google apps and tweak ever so slightly the basic operation of android
column22: I actually read a review where someone said Sense is too heavy
column23: at that point I knew he had not a clue
column24: and probably only spent 30 minutes with the phone. 5-Build
column25: HTC has been making very high quality phones for a very long time. Now
column26: the bad (or not so good is a better way to describe it)
column27: who knows the future of the company
column28: no business model would last when they keep losing money
column29: once google bought whatever is is they bought
column30: they seem to have turned their back on HTC. The high price-they are expensive and although they are a very high quality phone
column31: most people will never know because other phones are released at a high price and then basically given away after a month
column32: therefore most people won't shell out the money to get this phone.

column1: In closing
column2: my best advice
column3: ignore most of the reviews (haptic buttons are absolutely NOT a problem
column4: like too many people are stating) and take full advantage of the Amazon or HTC return policy
column5: I have a feeling that unless you are already loyal to a certain manufacturer you will find this is another fantastic phone from HTC. (no i'm not an HTC employee
column6: but I have bought most HTC phones since the HTC Inspire)";[('start'

column1: 5.0 out of 5 stars;Nice phone;I have always used HTC phones and this one is a really good phone so far. Its battery doesn't last that long

column7: you know it did not look like that just earlier. It doesn't always do this... just maybe once every 5 photos or so... When the picture doesn't become blurry after the fact

column1: 1.0 out of 5 stars;This phone's screen is too sensitive for basic daily use;"I'll start off with saying I don't hate HTC products. I've used their phones since the original Evo 4G
column2: and loved every little gimmick their phones would have. The audio from their latest phones back from the M9 was the sole reason I stuck with them
column3: the phone before this being an M9 that's still in perfect order today. It's as powerful as the rest and those earbuds that come with this phone are the best packaged in headphones to come with a phone ever.

column1: The bad part is how it's very obvious their phone division is suffering in durability lately. The pictures I took are of my phone after I had it in my pocket and was going to take a picture of something on Snapchat. This phone WASN'T dropped
column2: and for just sitting in my pocket
column3: the screen cracks. I've included my pictures to show the frame around the screen
column4: showing that there is no drop damage done like scratches or scuffs done to it at all. I have no clue if this is a defective screen or just bad build quality
column5: but this is a horrible use of Gorilla Glass I've ever seen.

column1: The worst part about this is with the evidence that I took and sent to HTC's repair center and asking they look into it as a defective screen
column2: but their repair center keeps claiming this is out of their warranty and will have to pay $200 to repair. If this was a one off screen that wasn't made correctly and repaired with warranty
column3: I wouldn't mind this at all
column4: but this is ridiculous that I have to pay for my phone damaging itself.

column1: So saddly
column2: I won't be getting anymore HTC phones
column3: especially given that these screens seem to also ca##NN##ot be removed as easily as some other phones for a DIY solution. I highly recommend avoiding this phone even as an HTC veteran.";[('will'

column1: 5.0 out of 5 stars;Hands down the best phone I've owned to date!;"After only 24 hours I can say I absolutely love this phone. I got used to the non button buttons right way (which seems to be critics biggest gripe.) The Edge Sense is really handy and takes little time to get used to. Set up was a breeze and since my previous phone was also an HTC it was super easy to import my phone settings and most of my apps from my previous handset.  I can already tell that the firmware update has improved the battery life (but is too early to say how much.)
The fingerprint reader is located on the back at the perfect spot
column2: and face recognition unlock is quite handy.

column1: The built in speakers are awesome and quite loud. Very clear sound and provide more bass than expected. The ear buds that come with the phone by far sound better than any others that I already own. Also I usually use Bluetooth speakers at work so the lack of a 3.5mm Jack does not bother me in the least.
My only small gripe is about the volume buttons
column2: you can't long press to turn volume all the way up/down
column3: you have to keep tapping the buttons level by level. However as soon as you do hit the buttons
column4: the volume level pops up on the screen
column5: so you can just adjust it from there
column6: so it's really a non issue.

column1: Also the plastic phone case that comes in the box seems cheap
column2: but it feels nice once you put it on the phone. It'll definitely do the job until I get around to buying another case.

column1: I'll update my review if the need arises.
Edit: The volume buttons will in fact turn the volume all the way up or down with one press. I don't know if it was the update our what
column2: But edge sense is more sensitive than it was the first day or so
column3: which is a good thing.";[('24'

column5: I just got a lemon.  Nope exact same problem with the new one.  I have updated all the latest software

column1: 3.0 out of 5 stars;Not the Phone for me;"I would like to say i tried. I tried to give HTC the benefit of the doubt and stand by their product. Unfortunately the HTC U12+ was not the device for me. The U12 has a lot to offer but fails in key areas which i would get to in a second. First let me mention the good:
Pros:

1. Video recording.  The U12+ is well built for this task. 3D audio and High Resolution audio was a feature i didn't think i needed until i used it and was shockingly amazed at the clarity and neat tricks it has to offer. I also came to like the ""Zoom Slider"" which helps zoom in and out a subject at a much smoother pace.
2. Rear Camera. The rear Camera is great. Pictures taken with it were up to today's smartphone standard. Portrait mode also works without flaw.
3. Fingerprint Reader. Fast
column2: Reliable and at just the right spot.

column1: 4. Call Quality: Crystal clear and loud enough to listen in any environment.
Cons:
1. Built Quality: Too fragile for my liking. The device is well built and beautiful but all that glass scares me.
2. Boomsound: This should be a positive but i honestly don't feel they are the loudest and do lack some Bass. Might be because they are not front facing.
3. Display: Its an LCD panel...... Its an LCD panel.... Its an LCD panel.

4. Front Facing Camera. Awful. They are not as bad as Samsung front facing cameras but they still leave a lot to be desired. Some people may enjoy the front facing camera due to how much it smooths faces
column2: making them look young but u##NN##atural . I turned off beautification mode and it still leans over to the smooth side.

column1: 5. Touch Buttons: OMG
column2: these are the worst. During the first 3 days of use i didn't face much problems as other online reviewers
column3: but once my protective case shipped in
column4: everything went downhill. I re-calibrated Edge Sense to account for the case but still ran into issues. Sometimes i had to force press the buttons
column5: other times they would register a press with the slightest touch. Using the phone became frustrating and i just couldn't continue happily owning it.

column1: In the end I decided to return the phone. Its a good phone but at this price tag it should of been an excellent phone.";[('htc'
column3: ('benefit'

column1: 5.0 out of 5 stars;Hands down
column2: the best phone I've ever owned;"I ordered this phone the first day it was available on Amazon. The issues with the touch-sensitive buttons were more than a little infuriating and shameful on HTC's part
column3: but once they released a software update to fix it (and some other tweaks that have now given me some stellar battery life) this phone can do no wrong. I have the translucent blue and it's a work of art.

column1: The screen is LCD
column2: not OLED as some of the descriptions say. No matter what size or color you get
column3: the screen is LCD. But it is gorgeous. There are no issues with polarization that used to be common with even the best LCD screens
column4: so polarized sunglasses won't black out the screen for you in certain orientations. The face unlock feature works extremely well
column5: but the fingerprint sensor is the best I've had on a phone. It has yet to fail.

column1: I'm a heavy user and my battery life easily gets me a full day's use and then some. I stream a lot of audio and have most apps set to push notifications. I don't stream much video
column2: but I do have the screen on quite a bit throughout any given day. Since the software update mentioned above
column3: my average battery life is around 29 hours
column4: with about 4 hours 45 minutes screen-on time
column5: and I usually plug in before the battery saver kicks in (at 15%). My best was 6 hours 52 screen-on time over nearly 36 hours. I plugged my phone in at 4% that day.

column1: The camera is phenomenal. HTC makes great cameras
column2: especially since the One M8 (though there have been a stinker or two in there)
column3: but this is a cut above all of them - and almost every other phone camera out there. I've used the newer Samsungs and LGs (though not the Pixel 2) and HTC just beats them handily. The dual camera setup takes amazing bokeh photos
column4: but it also allows for a 2X optical zoom that is great. Low light pics are great
column7: pro settings - they're all here and work great. I'm not a huge selfie taker
column8: but the dual front-facing cameras work well for it
column9: but also allow for a nice bokeh effect on selfies as well. Also
column10: the bokeh level is adjustable on both cameras prior to the shot.

column1: I love Edge Sense (the ability to launch apps or perform actions based on squeezing the side of the device). It sounds like a gimmick
column2: and lots of people say it is
column3: but most people who use it a little bit fall in love with it. Launching the camera
column4: taking a photo or a screenshot - all so much easier with Edge Sense. The tweaks they've made to it since it was launched with the U11 have made it much more useful and accurate. I especially love the Edge Launcher
column5: which is a small app carousel that shows up in the lower right corner
column6: allowing you to quickly access almost any of your apps and leaving your screen nice and clutter free.

column1: The included noise-cancelling headphones are the same as the U11 last year and they're fantastic. Unfortunately you'll be hard pressed to get them working in any other USB-C co##NN##ector. The included clear case is nice (again
column2: similar to the U11 last year) but it's a hard case and doesn't give the best protection. I went with the Spigen clear TPU case and it's great. Unfortunately the headphone to USB-C adapter that shipped with the U11 last year is not part of the U12+. You can still order it separately
column3: and if you have a nice set of regular headphones it is a must

column1: I'm using mine on T-Mobile and have no issues at all. The U12+ doesn't support the new Band 71 ( for some bizarre reason)
column2: though TMo just started rolling out Band 71
column3: so I'm not overly concerned. The phone won't work on Sprint
column4: but does work just fine on ATT and Verizon (with a few carrier limitations). I know some Verizon customers on here have complained about it
column5: but I know a few people who have it on Verizon and love it. Plus
column6: my son works for Verizon and has set up several w/ no issues.";[('ordered'

I have no regrets about this phone and I hope HTC stays around to make more phones so that when my 4 year old HTC finally dies I can invest in their newest offerings.";[('cell'

column1: 5.0 out of 5 stars;This one's a wi##NN##er;"The U12+ beautiful phone that is very practical. I was surprised
column2: though the screen is bigger than the U11's
column3: there body of the phone is a little thi##NN##er and more comfortable to hold.

column1: I found my favor for HTC after owning an M8 for two years
column2: and enjoying the outstanding boom-sound speakers it had to offer
column3: and then I made a terrible mistake and upgraded to a Samsung S7. I found favor with HTC phones because they don't put debilitating bloatware on your phone
column4: the UI is clean and unobtrusive (change what you want)
column5: and build quality is superb. I especially have grown to appreciate the 3D sound feature
column6: with the array of microphones all over their phones. As someone who spends a lot of time teaching music and working with a lot of pro live sound equipment
column7: I have found this feature far superior to the mics on other phones. HTC has definitely taken some risks that made their phones unique.

column1: The screen is LCD and not AMOLED
column2: but to my eyes I don't notice a difference. The screen is beautiful and very sharp
column3: a noticeable improvement over the U11.  The rest of the phone is made of glass. I was a bit swayed when I first looked at the U11
column4: but it is surprisingly durable. Truth is
column5: most people would most likely use a protective case anyway
column6: I chose the Spigen liquid crystal case for the U11
column7: and it took a quite beating with no damage whatsoever.

column1: Edge sense is AWESOME. I had the short squeeze programmed to turn on the camera
column2: and the long squeeze set to turn on a flashlight
column3: which I use frequently. It is nice to have both these functions  readily available without having to  search through the UI. Sadly double tap is very difficult to trigger without the liquid crystal case

column1: The buttons really aren't bad
column2: since the phone updated. The power and volume buttons aren't really physical buttons
column3: bit rather pressure-sensitive nubs that respond with haptic feedback. the power button actually responds better than it would with a physical button. The volume buttons take a little more getting used to
column4: and I am still getting used to them
column5: but they are very responsive and have given me no lag.  Battery life was really heavily criticized by the pro reviews.  I spent a lot of time with it my first 2 days just setting things up with the screen working heavily
column6: and the lowest it got was 32%. Normal use
column7: I ended my day at about 50%.

column1: This phone is TOTALLY for tech heads. You'll like this phone if you like having total control over your device
column2: and not having bloatware designed to nickel and dime you after you already shelled our $$$ for a phone. The speakers are great. They are a little lacking in Bass
column3: but a nice improvement over the U11
column4: and on par with the speakers of the S9 Plus.  The USonic headphones are phenomenal. You can mow your lawn and tune out the world. Just expect to not notice when someone is screaming at you.  So far this phone is extremely intuitive and I feel like it gets me.

column1: My advice if you go with this phone:
The U12+ will not work with Sprint.
If you use AT&T give your phone to a tech in a brick and mortar store. Make sure to tell them it is a factory unlocked phone.  So far
column2: VoLTE works fine
column3: but no Wi-Fi calling. I have heard contacting tier 2 tech support will hook everything up fine.

column1: Spigen liquid crystal case protects it and shows off its unique appearance. This is the best case you can get for it
column2: buttons will work perfectly
column3: but the double tap doesn't (the shock protection of the case works a little too well).";[('u12+'

column1: 3.0 out of 5 stars;Phone is good except glass and customer service;The phone is a good phone except the glass. Glass scratched within 36 days of owning just by picking up off table. Called customer support and even though only 6 days after warranty they were not willing to help.  They only would do repairs and don't even cover the cost of sending in the phone. I have owned their phones for years and put through hell in the military and never had an issue
column2: now new phone quality has gone down hill along with their support for customers. Probably why they don't sell them anymore in the US and have to buy directly through website or amazon. Went through 3 customers support people and yet nothing was resolved and tried to blame me for phone issues. Will never be going through them ever again when this phone is done. They had great phones in the past but seems they don't care about them or customers anymore.;[('good'

column1: Cons:
1. The included case is
column2: for all intents and purposes garbage so do yourself a favor and buy an upgraded one. I am very partial to the Spigen Liquid Crystal which has an amazingly low price for the protection but almost any other case will do.

column1: 2. This phone is so slippery that holding it or cradling it is like trying to run across a bowl full of vegetable oil and ball bearings so get a case or be extremely careful!
Welcome back HTC and please do your best to stay in the smartphone business!
***SEPTEMBER 8TH UPDATE***
Well here I am nearly 2.5 months later and my opinion has NOT changed. Even though the glass is Corning Gorilla Glass 3 as opposed to the latest Gorilla Glass 5
column2: 3 is more scratch resistant than 5 while 5 is more shatterproof. I have yet (knock on wood) to find a single scratch on my screen and as stated before
column3: mine sports the Spigen Liquid Crystal case. My phone lives in my pocket for most of the time and from what I've researched
column4: the Gorilla Glass 3 truly is the reason that I've yet to find a scratch so for those of you who know how unsightly
column6: and dissapointing a scratch can be on your screen...there was an engineering reason behind this choice as opposed to cost savings. I have also dropped it several times by mistake of course (usually getting out of the car and I forget that it's on my lap) and thankfully there's zero shattering of any kind and mind you that's landing on concrete and asphalt. To sum it all up
column7: I am just as pleased now as I was the day it arrived and my hat 🎩 continues to remain off to HTC for an excellent phone despite near dire financial straits. Rumors are begi##NN##ing to surface of the U13/U13+ so here's to hoping that they're true and that a year or less from now I'll be clutching one!";"[('htc'

5.0 out of 5 stars;Exceeded expectations.;I was looking for something that was high performance
column450: but did not have a notch or a hole in the screen. I loved my U11
column452: and she suggested I upgrade to the U12 Plus and give HER my beloved U11. Fortunately
column453: the U12 turned out to be a real beast
column454: and the haptic buttons have become a feature I like. The camera can go toe-to-toe with the Google Pixel in everything but Night Sight
column455: but it also has the telephoto camera which makes a big difference for someone who admires architecture. The primary camera is wide angle

column1: The screen is more beautiful than an LCD has a right to be
column2: and is just as vibrant as the Note 8 I use at work. For some reason
column3: my eyes do not get as tired with this phone
column4: and a friend and I watched an entire movie on it because it looked so good and the sound was so immersive. No distracting hole or notch either. It sounded better than my 4 inch stereo speakers on my desktop computer
column5: and we could still see when we were done ;)

column1: Headphone audio with the included earbuds is mindblowing. I don't take that statement lightly
column2: as I'm a professional studio recording engineer with 20+ years experience. I first experienced HTC's USonic audio on the U11
column3: and it took two weeks just to wrap my brain around the spatial imaging
column6: and bass extension. The noise cancellation works well at reducing engine noise and hum
column7: and these things actually scan your ears to optimize the sound. I know first had what it sounds like to stand in a commercial studio control room during a live mixdown session
column8: hearing the music in its original form
column9: and HTC USonic is the only technology that comes close to that experience.

column1: Performance wise
column2: it handles everything with ease
column3: including heavy gaming. Matter of fact
column4: it runs the game ARK: Survival Evolution fine
column5: while the new Galaxy S10 struggles with it. Battery life is something that is not great out of the box
column6: and that is because the U12 learns your usage patterns and optimizes battery usage accordingly. Give it two weeks to learn
column7: and the battery life will be better than phones which are said to have very good battery life. When you do need to charge
column8: it has Quick Charge 3.0 in the box
column9: and the phone is equipped for Quick Charge 4.0+. I get an initial charge of 2% every 60 seconds. The phone has power save and extreme power save modes
column10: but I've never had to use them. Ever.

column1: As far as feel is concerned
column2: I learned to appreciate quality over the years
column3: and the U12 Plus feels like it was carved out of emerald and then polished. Very dense
column5: and jewel-like. That's not to say it's not tough. I fell on it HARD last week
column6: and the impact left a phone-shaped bruise on my leg
column7: but the phone was fine. We also own the iPhone 8 Plus and XS Max
column8: and the U12 makes them feel like lower grade devices in comparison.";[('high'

column1: 4.0 out of 5 stars;HTC U12 is actually a great phone...and the 'professional' reviewers are wrong.;"I bought this on the HTC website and this phone is not nearly as bad as reviewers are saying on videos and other websites.  The phone is well built
column2: although slippery.  The case that comes with it is very good
column3: pretty much what you'd buy online.  Battery life is no where near as bad as people have said
column5: similar to the Galaxy S9 Plus.

column1: Pros: Fluidity/Speed
Bootloader can be unlocked
Video recording
Quick Charge 4.0
Camera with adequate lighting is amazing
HTC Sense almost feels as good as stock Android.
Front Cameras aren't great
column2: but they're better than most front cameras

column1: Boomsound gets loud and doesn't muffle
Transluscent Blue is stupid gorgeous.
Fingerprint sca##NN##er is very fast and responsive.
Face unlock is very good.
Not a lot of bloatware.
Display is not as good as AMOLED but it's still gorgeous and the brightness is a lot better than what reviewers have criticized it for.
Buttonless..and it's actually good.  I only had a couple accidental touches with the volume
column2: but not the power or double tap.

column1: Sense Edge 2.0 is a nice gimmick and it's not nearly as sensitive as reviewers have said.
New firmware coming that will update the buttons.
Cons: No wireless charging.  I get HTC's reason
column2: but it's so convenient.  I've been using wireless charging for years now and it sucks that I can't with this.

column1: Camera is grainy in low light.  It's typical of most phones
column2: but I guess the S9 plus is my baseline and that's the best low light camera I've personally used.  (I never used a P20 Pro)

column1: Doesn't come with a Quick Charge 4.0 charger
column2: so I bought a Razer Phone one.

column1: No 3.5mm jack and no 3.5mm to USB-C adapter.  Had to buy a Razer Phone one.
Edit: The camera in low light is actually really good if you put it in pro mode.  Just need to make a few adjustments and it's actually good.";[('bought'
